Dear Mr. Lingle:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
March 3, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
One of ten new employee files reviewed did not have a reference dated prior to hire.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or
other country where the person usually resides or has resided in
the previous 5 years.
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or other
country law enforcement agency where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
Two of ten new employee files reviewed did not have a criminal record check
completed prior to hire.
Repeat Violation Established: 2021 Interim, CAP approved 4/6/21
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
4

(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
Two of ten new employee files reviewed did not have a central registry check
completed prior to hire.
Repeat Violation Established: 2021 Interim, CAP approved 4/6/21
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
One of six new employee’s that required an evaluation did not have one completed
within the first 180 days of employment. One of four employees that have been
employed for over a year did not have the annual evaluation completed as required.
Repeat Violation Established: 2021 Interim, CAP approved 4/6/21
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
5

One of fourteen employees did not have a tuberculosis screening completed as
required.
Repeat Violation Established: 2021 Interim, CAP approved 4/6/21
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(6) Plumbing fixtures and water and waste pipes shall be
properly installed and maintained in good working condition.
Environmental Inspection found the wash pipe from kitchen sink to be clogged at
time of inspection.
R 400.4428 Sewage disposal.
Sewage and other water-carried wastes shall be disposed of
through a municipal sewer system where such a system is
available Where a municipal sewer connection in not available,
liquid waste shall be discharged into an approved private
system. The private system shall not create a nuisance or
pollute a stream, lake, or other body of water or contaminate a
water supply or bathing place and shall comply with applicable
local health departments requirements.
Environmental Inspection was unable to inspect the septic system and drain field
due to snow cover, temporary approval was provided until May 30, 2022.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility did not require or request technical assistance during the onsite
inspection. The facility was provided technical assistance, during the onsite of the
provisional license with the development of their corrective action plan. The facility
has been compliant with their corrective action plan and has not required additional
technical assistance. The consultant has maintained monthly unannounced visits to
the facility with no noted concerns.
6

V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require or request consultation during the onsite inspection. The
facility was provided consultation, during the onsite of the provisional license with the
development of their corrective action plan. The facility has been compliant with their
corrective action plan and has not required additional consultation. The consultant
has maintained monthly unannounced visits to the facility with no noted concerns.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
The period under review was March 9, 2021, through March 3, 2022. The facility was
placed on a first provisional license during this period under review on November 1,
2021. The facility has submitted six acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment, all of which were for violations prior to the current provisional license
period. One corrective action plan was in response to the interim report and five
corrective action plans were in response to special investigations resulting in the
provisional license. The facility has not had any special investigations since
September 8, 2021.
The corrective action plans that are currently being monitored are reviewed at least
quarterly. The main components of these corrective action plans include:
 Updating the staffing model to clearly outline staff schedule, ensuring a veteran
staff is on shift at all times, not including the program supervisor to count in ratio,
outlining the on-call schedule, having a program supervisor on shift between 7am
and 11pm to provide supervision and mentoring, and ensuring the deputy
director is notified when there is a staffing issue.
 To address staff deficiencies program supervisors have increased mentoring,
have increased observation, are providing monthly written feedback for staff,
monthly supervision sessions, training, and evaluations. Program supervisors are
providing this information to the deputy director for review and additional
feedback as needed.
 Developing a new hiring process to ensure all staff meet the educational
requirements of the position hired for. This new process includes the Chief
Administrator and Deputy Director reviewing and approving the employee files
before positions are offered to verify compliance.
 Facility distribution, implementation, and training of all corrective action plans to
ensure that all staff are aware and following required action steps. Additionally,
the process for oversite of all corrective action plans implementation and
compliance was changed to completing internal correct action plan reviews, team
meetings, individual and group supervision, and administrative meetings.
 Developing a new process on notification requirements to DCWL to ensure
compliance with the rules. The new process included additional oversight by
deputy director to ensure the notifications are being completed as required.
7

 The facility has a financial corrective action plan to combine two programs
(Teaching Family Homes and Associated Family Care) into one financial account
to provide additional financial stability and flexibility. The facility obtained loan
forgiveness for two large loans and has obtained a new annual audit.
 Not combining youth from Indian River and South Bluff due to staffing shortages,
retraining all staff on supervision expectations, monthly team reviews of
supervision policy. Additionally, they have action steps to ensure safety plan
implementation and monitoring. All safety plans are reviewed by program
supervisors, hung on the wall in the staff office, reviewed in team meeting, and
reviewed and signed by all staff.
The facility had four repeat violations:
 R. 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers. Previously
the facility had 5 of 6 employees that did not meet the requirements and during
this period under review had 1 of 14 employees that did not meet the
requirements.
 R. 400.4113 (j) Employee records/Evaluations. Previously the facility had 3 of
6 employees that did not meet the requirements and during this period under
review had 2 of 10 employees that did not meet the requirements.
 R. 400.4113 (f) Employee records/Criminal Background Clearances.
Previously the facility had 1 of 3 employees that did not meet the requirements
and during this period under review had 2 of 10 that did not meet the
requirements.
 R. 400.4113 (i) Employee records/Central Registry Clearances. Previously the
facility had 1 of 3 employees that did not meet the requirements and during
this period under review had 2 of 10 that did not meet the requirements.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
During this period under review the facility has changed Chief Administrators and
added a new Executive Director and there is a notable improvement in oversight, and
accountability which has decreased special investigations. There have been monthly
on-sight visits to the facility since October 2021. During these visits interviews were
completed with youth and staff. Youth consistently report feeling safe, having all their
basic needs met, and having appropriate therapy and programming to work on
treatment goals. The staff have all consistently reported that the change in Chief
Administrator and Executive Director has created a better work environment where
they feel supported and have consistency and direction. The staff report the
programming and overall safety for both youth and staff has greatly improved.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment documents the facility’s action steps to come into compliance and
maintain compliance with prior violations. The Chief Administrator notes the abrupt
change at the facility with the prior Chief Administrator leaving without notice and the
facility being without an administrator for a portion of the period under review. The
8

Chief Administrator outlines his current plan as administrator, which includes working
closely with executive director, program supervisors, social service worker, training
coordinator, recreation and nutrition coordinator, human recourse coordinator, and
program/administrative support to ensure the agency remains in compliance with the
current corrective action plans and contracts. In addition, Chief Administrator plans to
review all resident’s files 30 day from admission and annually thereafter for
compliance. As well as continuously work with the human resource coordinator to
ensure employee files are reviewed within 30 days of hire and annually thereafter.
Interviews
The staff interviewed all reported a feeling of support from administration. The staff
were able to speak to the current corrective action plans and compliance with the
action steps. The staff did not have any concerns about the facility or the safety for
themselves or the youth at the facility. The youth interviewed all reported feeling safe
at South Bluff. The youth all stated the staff were respectful and assisted them with
their treatment goals. The youth did not report any concerns about the facility.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility’s license be renewed to a regular license.
